articles.title: June '81
articles.summary: This document provides a detailed calendar of astronomical events and club activities for June and July 1981, primarily organized by the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). It outlines celestial phenomena like New Moons, meteor showers (June Lyrids, Northern Iota Aquarids), the Summer Solstice, and a partial lunar eclipse. The SJAA's schedule includes star parties, board and general meetings, a telescope makers' workshop, an annual slide and equipment night, an annual picnic, and participation in the Bay Area's Space Day event.

articles.title: SJAA EPHEMERIS
articles.summary: The SJAA EPHEMERIS is the monthly bulletin of the San Jose Astronomical Association, providing contact information for its editor and club officers. It also details membership options, including access to Sky & Telescope magazine, for adults and juniors, as well as a separate subscription for non-members.

articles.title: July 30 Total eclipse of the Sun, visible in the extreme North American, Alaska, and Arctic Regions. There will be a SJAA occultation expedition to various parts of the path.
articles.summary: A total solar eclipse is announced for July 30, visible across extreme North American, Alaskan, and Arctic regions. The SJAA (San Jose Astronomical Association) is organizing an occultation expedition to various parts of the eclipse path to observe this event.

articles.title: August 1 Stellafane Telescope Makers' Convention, Springfield, Vermont. Details in Observations.
articles.summary: This document announces the upcoming Stellafane Telescope Makers' Convention, scheduled for August 1 in Springfield, Vermont. Further details regarding the convention are stated to be available in the 'Observations' section of the document.

articles.title: Observations
articles.summary: The "Observations" column features several small announcements, noting that the club is currently in excellent condition regarding star parties, finances, and overall support. Members are encouraged to look forward to a summer filled with great observing opportunities.

articles.title: MT. UMUNHUM STAR PARTY JUNE 27
articles.summary: An announcement for a star party event scheduled for June 27 at Mt. Umunhum is provided. The article includes detailed driving directions to the observing site, information about a locked gate (combination 4565), and thanks Bobby Fingerhut for securing the location.

articles.title: MEMBERSHIP DUES NOW DUE
articles.summary: This article serves as a reminder that membership renewal dues are now payable. Treasurer Shea Pratt requests members to send in their Sky & Tel cards and checks promptly. Membership with Sky & Tel is $18/year, Junior membership is $12/year, and a Bulletin subscription is $7/year, with payment details provided for Shea Pratt.

articles.title: ELECTIONSELECTIONSELECTIONS
articles.summary: June marks election month for five board positions, and members are encouraged to submit nominations to the committee members listed. Nominees must meet specific eligibility requirements, such as a year of membership or attendance at six consecutive board meetings. Additionally, Steve Greenberg was recently elected to fill the remainder of Phil Hermansen's term on the board due to extended absences.

articles.title: IPICNIC!
articles.summary: The SJAA is hosting a free picnic for all members and associates on July 11, thanks to successful support for the recent auction. The event will feature complimentary hamburgers, hot dogs, and condiments, along with a potluck dish arrangement. Attendees are encouraged to mark their calendars and bring their families, with Portal Park as the hoped-for location.

articles.title: SHUTTLE LANDING PASSES
articles.summary: The article announces an opportunity for club members to watch the Space Shuttle Columbia land at Edwards Air Force Base in early October. Interested individuals are advised to write to the Office of Public Affairs at NASA's Dryden Flight Research Center for details, with a strong recommendation for the trip.

articles.title: STELLAFANE
articles.summary: The article invites members of SJAA to attend the Stellafane Telescope Makers' Conference on August 1st. It provides registration contact information and notes Stellafane's role as the East Coast's counterpart to the Riverside conference.

articles.title: THE DR. A.E. GREGORY AWARD
articles.summary: This article serves as a reminder for club members interested in nominating a peer for "THE DR. A.E. GREGORY AWARD." Members should contact Denni Fingerhut, Chris Pratt, or Kevin Medlock to submit their nominations.

articles.title: THE SJAA 12" TELESCOPE
articles.summary: Jay Freeman is leading the construction of a Dobsonian mount for the San Jose Astronomical Association's (SJAA) 12-inch Newtonian telescope, which is currently non-operational. Significant progress has been made, with an estimated completion time by early summer, and volunteers are encouraged to assist.

articles.title: WANT ADS
articles.summary: This document contains a series of want ads, primarily for astronomical equipment. Items listed for sale include a C-8 telescope with accessories, components for a 14" fork-mounted telescope, a 6" Vega Maksutov, and an HP 41C calculator. Additionally, the SJAA is selling Skalnate Pleso's desk edition.

articles.title: ASTRONOMY DAY '81
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) held a highly successful Astronomy Day '81 with over 600 public viewers across three sites, benefiting from clear skies and warm weather. Key celestial objects like Jupiter, Saturn, and the Moon were observed, alongside fainter targets such as M-51 and M-83, providing many first-time viewers with memorable experiences, including a remarkable observation of Io's reappearance. The event successfully engaged the public, distributed brochures, and attracted potential new members to amateur astronomy.

articles.title: COE STAR PARTY REPORT
articles.summary: This document chronicles two amateur astronomy events: a challenging but ultimately successful star party at Henry Coe State Park in May, where participants braved cold, wind, and dew to enjoy clear skies and steady viewing with 8-inch telescopes; and the 13th annual Riverside Telescope Makers' Conference in Big Bear, a large gathering featuring over 1000 attendees, numerous telescopes, and lectures from notable figures like Bart Bok. Both reports emphasize the dedication of amateur astronomers despite adverse conditions, highlighting successful observations and the vibrant community spirit.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS
articles.summary: The article provides an update on several comets, noting that Comets Meier and Borrelly have faded while Comet Panther persists and Comet Bowell is slowly brightening as a telescopic object near Jupiter. It also announces the discovery of two new faint comets, Elias (1981c) and Bus (1981d), detailing their discovery location, magnitude, and expected brightness, with neither anticipated to get much brighter.

articles.title: Comet Panther (1980u)
articles.summary: Comet Panther (1980u) is rapidly fading as it pulls away from both the sun and Earth, moving from the constellation Cancer into Leo. Its magnitude is decreasing from 10.7 in late May to an estimated 12.1 by early July. The comet will become unobservable by early July due to its close proximity to the sun.

articles.title: Comet Bowell (1980b)
articles.summary: This document provides an ephemeris for Comet Bowell (1980b) from late May to early July, detailing its Right Ascension, Declination, and magnitude. It notes the comet's proximity to Jupiter during May, its distance of approximately 4 AU from the sun, and indicates which magnitude estimates are likely more accurate.

articles.title: GREAT COMETS
articles.summary: This article details Comet Bowell (1980b), discovered at a record 7.2 AU from the sun, and notes its interaction with Jupiter which increased its speed, destined to leave the solar system after its closest approach to the sun next March. Currently magnitude 12 with a short tail, it is expected to brighten to magnitude 9. Additionally, it mentions "Star Date," a two-minute astro-talk available on KCBS radio.

articles.title: THE CELESTIAL TOURIST SPEAKS
articles.summary: The article details the author's recent deep-sky observing sessions, primarily at Fremont Peak using a Celestron 14, where he explored numerous galaxies in clusters within eastern Leo and Coma Berenices, and specific objects like NGC 4565 and NGC 6543. It provides descriptive accounts of these observations through various telescopes and magnifications. Additionally, the author presents a humorous list of satirical awards for telescope enthusiasts, reflecting on common experiences in amateur astronomy.
